Wow. We've spent three days here at my aunt's and it's been amazing. We've gone and experienced the seediness that is Tijuana and the craziness at Pacific Beach. We went surfing with my uncle Jorge and eaten like kings here at the house. And it's been amazing, relaxing, and just incredible. They've taken us in and seem to have enjoyed having us here as much as we've enjoyed staying... maybe even more so, if that's possible. I haven't blogged much in the past few days because I've just been enveloped in being here, in experiencing it with every fiber of my being. Blogging just didn't fit into that plan too well. Now I'm back, and I'm sure Kinko's will assist in that regard. I've rediscovered the wonders of Southern California while I've been here. The natural beauty and the amazing climate are just perfect. I am making mental plans to move here when I finish college in two years. Anyone who is cool and wants in is most welcome. I'll be damned if I know how I can recreate an artistic niche out here, but I bet I can make it happen. Life is too short to not follow my dreams, and this is one of them. Tomorrow, Dan and I set out north up the coast on the Pacific Coast Highway. We're making a stop in Santa Monica to see some old friends of mine, Dan and Pete. I'm looking forward to that. I haven't seen them in at least a year, probably longer. Then we make for San Francisco, camping up the coast. The only place that I know of that I want to stop is Big Sur. Other than that, the sky's the limit. And we've already shown that lack of planning makes for an awesome trip. So who knows what's going to happen? Surely not me. I can't wait. San Diego has been the perfect stop after about 3300 miles on the road, and there are many more things ahead of us to enjoy. Whether camping, hostelling, or crashing with newfound friends, the remainder of the trip is promising to be as good if not better than the first. It's all about how I perceive it. And right now, I can't imagine it being anything short of great. For now, that will do. Missing you all, but having the time of my life... I'm still Ehren

Well, the day started out as normal for us Californians.... surfing in the Pacific amidst stingrays and a beautiful San Diego morning. Oh man... so much fun. It was my first time surfing and I actually think I did pretty well considering. Of course I was never able to really stand up on my board and ride a bodacious wave into the surf. However, there was a couple of waves that I got and was able to ride on in on my knees. It was really thrilling... totally exhilarating, especially that moment just before you catch a wave where you're paddling in front of it as hard as you can (really tiring work) and then suddenly you feel the wave pick you up and it just carries you all the way in. So cool... I highly recommend it to anyone who wants a new experience... now that I'm a professional I'll have to take some of you out. Anyway, we then had a quick breakfast and some showers and then it was off to Tijuana for the afternoon. Now, the Tijuana experience was unlike anything I've ever encountered. Ehren and I parked just about a mile away from the border on the US side and then walked over to Tijuana. I tell you all honestly, I don't think I've ever been to a city that has presented itself with such thorough repugnance. It was ridiculous, in every corner, every step down the street, there was a new person accosting me to come into his store. Or it was some kid coming up to me trying to sell me some little trinket, it was thoroughly annoying. And lest we forget that it was a total tourist trap... every little peddler that came up to me pushing his "unique" and "well-priced" store, was just another in a long chain of stores selling the same ridiculous crap. I think at the end I was so fed up with it all that one guy came up to me saying, "Hey amigo, come on check out my store... I give you good prices." And my reply was, "Oh sorry, I visited your other store down the street." I know I was probably a little harsh... these guys are just trying to make a living, but man... they were obnoxious. At one point Ehren and I got roped into going a bar by the guy out front telling us he would give us a free shot of his best tequila...(watered down Cuervo that is) or so we found out. We went up four flights of stairs to this seedy bar at the top, and immediately were roped into buying two shit beers... albeit for only a buck each... which I can't argue with. But the part that pissed me off was this guy who kept coming around and what he would do was wrench your head back between his arms and then hold you while he poured tequila down your throat, all the while blowing this whistle. And then he would stop, slap on the head, and then take you and jiggle you around. Fucking ridiculous. And then, after he had done this to me... he would demand that I pay for the tequila... what the fuck! Not only had he poured nasty tequila down my throat against my will and then asked us to pay for it, but I was promised free tequila... We were totally ripped off. Well, anyway, after this happened to both Ehren and I twice, and we had shelled out money for something we didn't want, we decided that we needed to leave before we were roped into spending any more money. Totally Ridiculous. So... my vote is a big thumbs down on Tijuana. If you're 18 or 19 and can't drink in the states, and are stupid and haven't realized that you can get alcohol from pretty much anywhere you want just by asking your good 21 year old friends, then go down to Tijuana... you may slimly get your money's worth. But otherwise... stay away... it's a toursit trap. What pissed me off more was that I only went down there to get a couple of Cuban cigars to brink back to some friends, but all the cigar places we went, very nice places surprisingly, all the cigars were so overpriced that I wasn't able to pick up any. Would you believe $29.00 dollars for a single cigar. Ridiculous. Anyway, enough of my tirade... tomorrow Ehren and I are hitting the beaches for another welcomed day of relaxation... besides, I need to work on my California tan... it suprising how many people know you're from the Northeast just by your tan line. But... anyway, that should be fun... More later.. -dj

Well, we decided to change our plans. Hitting Bryce Canyon and Grand Canyon on the outbound trip is just too far out of the way. Check it out on a map… it’s much further north than I’d figured. But we’re going to hit it on the way back across the country on our way to Colorado. That’s the best part of this road trip – no set itinerary. So if we decide to drive to California instead of Utah, then it’s just another adventure and no harm done. Hundreds, if not thousands, of miles of prairie and desert await us and my little Corolla. I should do an ad for Toyota. We found a state park in Kerrville, Texas this evening with the intention of camping there and leaving around 4am for Bryce Canyon. But when we got there, we discovered that the office was closed, they lock the gate at 10pm and don’t open it until 8am… a significant kink in the plans. So after a bit of brainstorming, we just decided to cook dinner there and use their showers (which were AMAZING by the way, water pressure that would almost knock you over and lots of free hot water), then set out for another long drive that is going to end with us getting to San Diego tomorrow evening around the time Marianne gets out of work. Dan and I are now road warriors. In 6 days, we’ve left Connecticut, spent two full days in New Orleans, an afternoon in San Antonio and will reach San Diego, California before sundown on the sixth day… three thousand, two hundred and ninety nine miles later. Why the hell doesn’t everyone do this? And often? Man, to get out and see the world, I thought I needed to travel to exotic foreign lands with a passport. Turns out all I need is a car and a sense of adventure. There’s enough foreign lands in this country to teach me for a good long while.

We’re driving through Beaumont, Texas right now. Well, Dan is driving – I’m riding, but you get the idea. Our drive this morning through southern Louisiana was amazing. The interstate that goes west from New Orleans toward Texas travels for miles and miles through the bayou. That is, the road is an elevated causeway supported by concrete poles above miles and miles of swamp. With nowhere to pull off, it was pretty much impossible to take any good pictures… and the ones we took from the road were mostly of the guardrails bounding the road. There were lonely power lines stretching from nowhere to nowhere through the murk on tall thin poles, and an occasional motored skiff moored to the highway support with a couple people fishing. Sometimes we would travel through a small piece of land surrounded by swamp with no highway exit, and there were little houses whose only access lay in boats through the bayou. It’s a different way to live, isolated in an odd way far different from that of northern New England. When you’re up in the mountains, there is nothing around… no people, no interstates, no passers-by… nothing. In those places by the highway, people pass by all the time on the interstate, but there is no connection between the cars and the inhabitants of the bayou. All we can do is look at each other and ruminate what the other’s life is like. Last night Dan and I went to Preservation Hall in New Orleans, the birthplace of jazz. Guidebooks would call it quaint and rustic. In reality, it’s a dump. But it’s a dump oozing with tradition and history. The place is a wooden building in a city of brick. No air conditioning, sweltering heat, wooden planks for benches and old tired cushions on the floor for seating. If you’re in the back, you stand. This is a place that’s all about the music. If you want other niceties, you may as well go somewhere else. That it’s lasted as long as it has is a miracle in and of itself. But the music that happens inside each night is nothing short of amazing. This was without a doubt the best jazz I have ever heard in my life. The band had seven instruments – piano, bass, banjo, clarinet, trumpet, trombone, and drums. Each was a master of their instrument, but their real talent was in their ability to play off each other, commenting on each other’s ideas to create a dynamic tapestry of sound unlike anything I’ve ever heard. Had an odd dream last night about an old crush (actually, my only one ever… I’ve never really been into crushes) that suddenly came back into my life. We hit it off, and started dating. I have no idea where she actually is right now… haven’t talked with her in years. I had a thing for her all through high school but didn’t have the guts to ask her out… she went to a different school, we’d met at music camp… you get the picture. By the time I finally did develop testicles, she’d met this other guy. Dammit. She remains the one who got away. Whether it would have ever worked, who knows? But my memories of her are all great, and I’d love to have the chance to find out. Last I knew she was going to Westminster to study choral conducting and had a boyfriend. Both of which probably make the dream a moot point. But it was nice while it lasted. Tomorrow, San Antonio. I can’t wait to show Dan some of the stuff I’ve seen there and discover even more. I want to see the Riverwalk, the Alamo, and some of the old Spanish Missions that stretch south from the city. My goal is to not get bitten by any fire ants while at the missions (Meg, that one’s for you!) Is the audioblog working? I tried to set it up and post, but I think I fucked it up. I’ll get it eventually. Picture posting is going to be a no-go for a while because the USB port on my computer is dead, and I need that to link up with the camera. I guess you’ll all have to wait for them till later. Heading back to the real world. Ehren out.

6/22/2004 1:59 PM Last night, our last night in New Orleans, was simply amazing. I think I may have seen and heard the best jazz of my life. We went to the Preservation Hall jazz club in the heart of the Old Quarter of New Orleans. It really is this little shit hole in the wall, hasn’t changed much in a hundred years… you walk in and sit on these long wooden benches in a dark, small.. un-airconditioned room.. lit only by two light bulbs over the area where the musicians played. All around us on the walls were these blackened pictures of old jazz musicians, and it all smelt very musty. The band started playing at around 8:15 and we stayed for two sets until 9:30. Awesome. I don’t know really how to describe the music… it was earthy, it was so real.. alive. It was the only the music that I can remember that had so much personal character infused into its production. These guys were good... they all knew all the traditional requests that were made by the people, and they played them all so well, each having a 1 or 2 minute solo in the the middle. Just Awesome. So anyway, after that we went out onto Bourbon street to have some fun on our last night in town. We started by just hitting some bars, each one having a different type of music playing. There was even a karaoke bar which Ehren and I entertained the possibility of performing in a little later on in the night. We then went to this bar to try one of Bourbon streets famous “Hand Grenades” – “New Orleans most powerful drink.” We tried it… it was good.. Ehren got drunk-ish, I was happy too. After we hung out at that place for a while we were pretty much tired out. We walked around Bourbon street for a while and then finally made it back to the hostile at around 1 am. Another great night. That city was entirely too much fun. I really hope I’ll make it back there some day.. we need to bring all our friends there some time because it would be an awesome place to party. So… now we’re on the road again heading for San Antonio, Texas. We’re just about at the border of Louisianna and Texas now having driven for four hours. Texas, although we are breaking it up with some camping excursions, is going to a long state to drive through… it’s already getting flat and boring. I can’t wait to get up to the deserts of New Mexico and Utah… and Bryce Canyon, it’s supposedly beautiful land out there. Oh… I forgot to mention… we went to this Old Quarter French market during the day yesterday and bought Loki this awesome toy. One of those weevle balls with a tail. He is gonna go ape over it. Well anyway, we’re about to stop at a rest stop just over the Texas border.. More will come later.. P.S.- I miss you Ali. Love you. –Dan

Well, this is our secodn day in New Orleans and all I can say is wow. Rarely have I been to a city with so much history coursing through it. We've been spending most of our time in the Old Quarter, pretty much just walking around. We went to the New Orleans Voodoo museum yesterday, that was pretty cool. I learned alot about something of which I had really no knowledge. The great thing about this road trip is that it's so free. There are no plans whatsoever. For instance we had originally planned to stay only until today, but we liked it so much that we decided to stay an extra night. We didn't get an oppurtunity to go to Preservation Hall last night to hear some jazz, so hopefully we'll get back to that place sometime tonight and check it out. Preservation Hall is the funniest little place. All it is this run-down shack of a building in the middle of the old quarter, that every night just has amazing jazz musicians coming through it. I just finished a five-hour stint of driving, which brought us from Connecticut through New York, New Jersey, and Delaware to Maryland around exit 93 on I-95. Already, we have had some serious adventures. Our map program is not as infallible as we thought. Going through New York City, it snaked us down the east side into Queens on 295. The highway ended on us abruptly, confusing me a whole hell of a lot. On the bright side, we needed gas anyway and it spit us out right in front of a Mobil station. On the down side, the only was out of New York was through – straight through. I had the driving adventure of a lifetime. Sometime around midnight we ended up in Lower Manhattan in the Bowery. Our goal: the Holland Tunnel to take us to Jersey. Dan’s navigational skills and my amazing driving brought us through without a hitch, which was just freaking cool. I learned something about driving in New York… it’s a lot like driving in Boston, except a lot more so. He who hesitates is dead, so to speak. So you just GO, you just drive with an exacting blend of reckless abandon and steely-eyed precision, with a bit of a balls-out attitude toward it all. If there’s a spot, you jam on the gas pedal and make it yours, because nobody is going to give it to you. In some ways, it’s like a high-stakes game of chicken. It was exhilarating. It was a blast. It took all my concentration and then some. But we emerged without a scratch and without any close calls at all. It’s 3:58am and I am not really tired. A bit out of it, yes, but driving for 5 hours will do that to you. At this point, my excitement for the whole trip and adrenaline are keeping me going. I think it’s the same for Dan. And while it lasts, we’re banging out as many miles as we can. Road weariness will set in eventually, and we’ll sleep when we need to. But for now, it’s full speed ahead.

The trip is over. I'm back in Connecticut, though still "on the road" in some aspects due to the fact that I don't have a home yet. We left Boulder on a Monday morning after spending three nights there with Roz and Johnny McClellan for Liberty, Missouri -- just outside of Kansas City, Missouri -- to stay with Jay and Melissa Carter. Staying in Liberty with Jay and Melissa was a great time. The first night, we went to hang out on the campus of William Jewell College... for the uninformed, the alma mater of Jay, Melissa, Mark and Kristen Singleton, and Dave Pettyjohn. This is why I didn't post from Liberty -- in my immortal words, it was too hot to shit, and certainly too hot to write. Tuesday night we went out to the Ameristar casino, where I discovered the wonders of playing casino blackjack and not just sticking to video poker machines. I los about $40 by the time all was said and done but played for hours... but Dan won $30! He was making all sorts of crazy bets like doubling down to a seventeen and pulling it off by drawing a four to make twenty-one. It was a great night. Wednesday found us leaving Liberty for Fort Wayne, Indiana to stay with Jenny Williamson's dad, Earnie. It's good to be back. But I can see now, more clearly than ever, that my days in this state are numbered. Its redeeming factor is my friends. And that, for now, is plenty. Well... here we are. Ehren is in the shower at the moment, so I thought I'd take a few to write a bit. Our time in Boulder was everything that serenity can encompass. The McClellan's, my sister's boyfriend's parents, have a beautiful house in the mtns. outside of Boulder, just to the east of the Rockies and the Continental Divide. The view is stunning. Maybe I'm a little biased, but I have to say that this is one of my most favorite stops of this trip. I had never been out here before and all that I had heard was through my sister... who in her somewhat cavalier way, never truly described how beautiful it was. The McClellans have the cutest cat... clearly she rules superior throughout the house... currently she's right in front of me while I'm trying to type, demanding attention.. Hold on... .. The house is perched between mtns. in a valley just by what the McClellans call Twin Sisters Peak. Ehren and I hiked this mtn. with them a few days ago and were stunned by the amazing 360 degree view of CO at the time. Also... it was amazing to hear how quiet it was out there... and at the cabin as well. In CT, even when you're hiking through the forest (what forest?) you always have the sense that civilization is just looming around every corner. Here, however, is a total escape. It takes two dirt roads and one that goes up a mtn to visit the cabin... civilization is left far behind. And thus, it's just peaceful... the cares of the world seem to float away up here and you are left to enjoy the natural beauty that is all around us, but that we never notice. Last night I think I saw the most amazing, star-filled sky that I have ever seen. We were having a cookout with the McClellans at their second cabin, about two miles away. While the main cabing has all the modern conveniances of any New York house... the smaller cabin is just a cabin... with well-water and no electricity, save for a little battery attached to a solar-panel (like something that Thoreau could have written about, only with probably nalied boards)... but it is here that one can truly find a natural sanctuary. Left without all the distractions of the world, one really realizes how many singular thoughts race through one's head. We joked and talked about politics, philosophy, and all sorts of subjects... we sang around the campfire on Ros's old classical guitar... it was a great night. And the food was awesome too. Ehren and I had bought these garlic and roasted pepper sausages that were really really good, and we roasted corn inside tin foil in the hot coals of the fire... really tasty, we'll have to do it up in vt next time. But anyway... the stars were exquisite. I saw constellations surrounding other constellations that I never even knew existed... and the big dipper... probably the only thing I can really recognize... was ginormous... like it had been strung into the site by a giant lasso... simply amazing. Well, anyway, I could go on forever talking about every little detail that I found amazing about this place. It is beautiful, and I feel honored to have had the McClellans share it with me for a while. It is their perfection. More later... time to shower...

DESERATA Go placidly amid the noise and haste, & remember what peace there may be in silence. As far as possible be on good terms with all persons. Speak your truth quietly & clearly; and listen to others, even the dull and ignorant; they too have their story. Avoid loud & agressive persons, they are vexations to the spirit. If you compare yourself with others, you may become vain & bitter; for always there will be greater and lesser persons than yourself. Enjoy your achievements as well as your plans. Keep interested in your own career, however humble; it is a real possession in the changing fortunes of time. Exercise caution in your business affairs; for the world is full of trickery. But let this not blind you to what virtue there is; many people strive for high ideals; Be yourself. Especially, do not feign affection. Neither be cynical about love; for in the face of all aridity & disenchantment it transcends time and space. Take kindly the counsel of the years, gracefully surrendering the things of youth. Nurture strength of Spirit to shield you in sudden misfortune. But do not distress yourself with imaginings. Many fears are born of fatigue and loneliness. Beyond a wholesome disipline, be gentle with yourself. You are a child of the universe, no less than the trees & the stars; you have a right to be here. And whether or not it is clear to you no doubt the universe is unfolding as it should. Therfore be at peace with God, whatever you conceive God to be, and whatever your labors & aspirations, in the noisy confusion of life keep peace with your soul. With all its shame, drudgery & broken dreams, it is still a beautiful world. Be Careful. Take Care. Strive to be Happy. (Found in old St. Pauls Church in Baltimore circa. 1692 -- Writer unknown)

I don’t know what I expected of this place. Maybe nothing at all – an experience with no preconceived notions, I don’t know. But however I got here, this place is a mixture of nature and nirvana. It’s what you would expect if you put Montgomery, Vermont in some real mountains instead of those rolling hills that Vermont has to offer. I’m just east of the Continental Divide right now, in a cabin owned by Dan’s sister’s boyfriend’s parents. They’re extremely nice folks, salt of the earth type. I guess you have to be to live out here, so isolated from people. Their property is smack in the middle of the Roosevelt and Arapaho National Forests, so there’s no worries about anyone ever spoiling the scenery with big houses or other development. The setting begs for reflection and spiritual contemplation. Being such an integral part of nature out here also serves to provide some much-needed perspective into many things. The silence is deafening, until you open your ears and hear all the sounds of the woods around you. We drove up Mt. Evans today. At 14,260 feet tall, it’s the highest I’ve ever been in my life – and certainly the highest my little car has ever ventured. Up until this trip, the highest she’d ever traveled was 6,280 feet up the Mt. Washington Auto Road. We got snowed on today on the top of this mountain. Yes, snow. In July. That’s what fourteen thousand feet will do to you, I guess. I also got high today… from the altitude and lack of oxygen on top of the mountain. It was curious how the air just seemed to be thin, and completely useless where breathing was concerned. It just wasn’t enough for my system. I got dizzy and couldn’t talk or think straight. A very curious experience altogether, and one I’d recommend if you get the chance just to see what it feels like. Just don’t drive off the edge of the road on the way up – there are no guard rails, just steep cliffs to tumble over. This evening, Dan and I went into Boulder and found this “mall” that is basically like a really clean and artsy Fanueil Hall from Boston. Lots of street performers and cool stores characterize this area of the downtown that’s been set aside solely for pedestrian traffic. We later found a dueling piano bar called The Reef and hung out there for a few hours. Connecticut needs a place like that. Oh, and fans of The Onion will be interested to know that it’s published here. Well, here and in Denver. It’s available in print for free on the street. How cool is that? Sleep is calling. I plan on picking up and having a nice long conversation. Hope everyone is well. Sleep loose.

Well, I pretty much thinhk that Ehren summed at least the details of our trip the past couple of days. I remember fondly a billboard that Ehren and I saw while in San Fran it read. "The reason settlers came to the east first was because if they came to California, they never would have left." (Or something like that) But how true it is. Everytime I go to California I can't help bu feel an overwhelming sense of serenity... I don't really know why. It's just beautiful. Driving up the coast and seeing the beauty of ocean meeting land... whether it be by way of cliff or beach, to the bold beauty of the Yosemite Valley. All of these places are different... but yet all in California. Any preconception or judgement I had made about the physical beauty of the earth was totally blasted away and redefined by this one state. I came down the trail... a long trail, too tired at the moment to really care what I was about to see, but then it hit... the largest living thing on the earth, and who would have thought it'd be a tree. It's so simple... trees have such simple lives... most of them anyway. They live, grow, and then at some point die... most likely from weather changes. But these trees were different, soaring into the air, their barked charred in some places from past forest fires. These trees were older than Christ. Almost 3500 years old. Man, it’s been a long time since the last blog from the Hyatt in San Francisco. It seems an age ago. And yet it’s been what, four days? Let’s start where I left off -- with the trip east from San Francisco toward Yosemite. We stopped in the desert town of Oakdale, California for some Taco Bell, an oil change, and some provisions. The guys who changed our oil (one young, one old) were easily the nicest and most useful mechanics I’ve ever met. I think that our plates said Connecticut broke the ice pretty quickly. Their oil change service included vacuuming and washing of our windows – inside AND out. Okay, on to Yosemite. Yosemite National Park was unbelievable. I have tons of pictures, which I’ll post as soon as I can, but this trip into the wilderness was amazing. Our campground was off the path. Way off. We drove down a 3 mile switchback road that said simply “ROUGH ROAD”. What an understatement. It was like driving an obstacle course. At one time the road had been paved, but ever since it had been left to its own devices. Washouts and deep potholes were everywhere. Often it was easier and safer to drive on the dirt shoulder – when there was one! Other times the road dropped off on the side. Once we made it down, the campground was isolated and beautiful, just the way I like it. We were almost the only people there, save two other families who had braved the trip down that road. The following day, Dan and I explored Yosemite Valley. We soon found a waterfall, Bridalveil Falls, parked the car, and hiked up in to the base of the falls. I soon found all my rock-climbing skills honed in Maine and northern New Hampshire in demand as we scrambled up and over boulders and around rocks to get closer than the path brought us and to get away from the legions of tourists who seemed unable to leave the path. Later on, we found another waterfall, Yosemite Falls, which is apparently the fifth tallest waterfall in the world at something around 2700 feet. We did the hike and scramble thing again, but at the base of this one we found a huge pool for swimming that had been carved into the rock by eons of water erosion. So we went swimming – Dan in his khakis, me in my shorts. Man, was it cold. But being able to swim and really move around warmed me up. For a bit, at least. Eventually my feet started going numb and my joints started getting that stupid feeling, so I headed for the rocks. The next day – July seventh, if I’ve got the dates right – we headed east through the upper part of the park on the Tioga Road, through cliffs (literally!), around boulders, past subalpine meadows, and all the other beautiful things that make up the Sierra Nevada Mountains. I can see why John Muir loved this place so much. As we left the park, we crossed Tioga Pass at an altitude of 9,945 feet – the highest I’ve been to date and certainly the highest my car has ever driven. This will all be remedied tomorrow as we drive through the Rocky Mountains and cross the Continental Divide en route to Boulder, Colorado. But I’m getting ahead of myself. Today, we explored Bryce Canyon National Park in southwestern Utah. I now understand why everyone kept telling me that I just had to go there. The place is awe-inspiring in every sense of the phrase. The land is a combination of limestone and sandstone. They erode at different speeds, creating the dramatic landscape of steep dropoffs and columns of rock called hoodoos that are tenacious remnants of old land masses. Everything simply eroded around them, leaving these strange-shaped things I can only describe as stalagmites, except they’re not in a cave. So you might just have to wait for the pictures on this one. We took a hike down into the canyon and walked in and around and under and through all these things. I kept forgetting about the high altitude of the place – about 7,000 feet – and continually wondered why I got so tired so quickly. Typical me, I guess… And now we are in the car just west of Grand Junction, Colorado, where we plan to stop for a break. There’s no Kinko’s here, but we’re going to try and fake it. Either we’ll find some other place to connect to the Internet, or we’ll cruise the residential streets of Grand Junction in hopes of finding some Net-dummy who can’t lock down their wireless network and surf from the street. Or we’ll just fail on all attempts and connect in Boulder. We’ll see. Hey, the trip’s all about adventure, right?

Happy fricking Fourth of July. The day we celebrate blowing shit up and killing people. Yay us. Wait -- yay US. Dan and I went down to the water to watch the fireworks tonight. It was a lazy day after the bullshit of getting rained on last night, so neither of us felt like braving the madness down at Pier 39. So we found a long pier somewhere around 15 or 20 or so with a whole mass of other people and went out to the end and waited. Had a great view. Or so we thought. Fate had other ideas. The fog that makes San Francisco so famous rolled in around 8pm. Fireworks were due to start around 9pm. 9 came and went. The breeze kicked up and chilled us down but good. Eventually, we had a distant show of Oakland's fireworks show going on across the bay. Looked like a good one, too... just really small and far off. People set off firecrackers here and there. There was also the occasional firework set off from within the city -- a huge no-no, I'm sure, but fun to watch. Finally, around 9:30, we heard booms from the area of Pier 39. And lights began to flash from behind the long building in front of us. And that was all we would get. For some reason, fireworks shows out here take place awfully low to the ground. To hear some residents talking, this was very unusual -- usually they could see the show from where we were. But tonight? No dice. I don't know if it was the wind, or the fog, or what, but the show was just too damn low to see. On the way out was the best part of the show. Some kid my age tossed an M80 in the water next to us as we were leaving the pier, which went off with a boom like a car bomb. Scared the piss out of me. But I actually enjoyed it. Needed something to explode after the letdown San Fran put on for us. Still, though -- it was a great day and evening, despite the cocktease of a fireworks display. Dan and I bummed around the city and hotel, and generally had a grand time doing not much at all. Tomorrow, we're off for Yosemite. I'm going to miss California and the Pacific. I need to live here after grad school. Two more years. Maybe we should all buy a house out here and get like 8 or 10 people in on it. Shoot our own Real World or something. Hey, I can dream, can't I?

Life is simply too short to waste. Society tells us that things are important. They're not. Society tells us that things don't matter. They do. They tell us that we need this car or that brand of pants... that we can measure our worth by buying the wares that they are trying to hock. It's a load of shit. The most important thing I've got is myself. Without that, I'm nothing. But my friends are a close second. Maybe even a tie. Making sure I am wearing the latest in Gap fashions? Somewhere near the bottom of page 5 on the list. But having close friends? People I can trust? That's worth far more than anything I could ever own. Because I don't own my friends. I can't. And I wouldn't want to. They're my friends because they want to be. And that's one of the most precious things in the world. Anyone who tells you different is trying to sell you something. And they're either lying... or they really do think that our worth comes from our possessions. The question is, which is worse? If you need me, I'll be looking for my copy of Thoreau.

My buddy Dan introduced me to a poet a while back named Pablo Neruda. His imagery is incredible... if I could write about why I am an artist... why I am a musician... this would be it. POETRY Pablo Neruda And it was at that age...Poetry arrived in search of me. I don't know, I don't know where it came from, from winter or a river. I don't know how or when, no, they were not voices, they were not words, nor silence, but from a street I was summoned, from the branches of night, abruptly from the others, among violent fires or returning alone, there I was without a face and it touched me. I did not know what to say, my mouth had no way with names my eyes were blind, and something started in my soul, fever or forgotten wings, and I made my own way, deciphering that fire and I wrote the first faint line, faint, without substance, pure nonsense, pure wisdom of someone who knows nothing, and suddenly I saw the heavens unfastened and open, planets, palpitating plantations, shadow perforated, riddled with arrows, fire and flowers, the winding night, the universe. And I, infinitesimal being, drunk with the great starry void, likeness, image of mystery, I felt myself a pure part of the abyss, I wheeled with the stars, my heart broke loose on the wind. I got a letter today from the Honors Program, informing me that I would "be returned to the regular program on October 31 UNLESS [they hear] OTHERWISE BY 12:00 NOON ON OCTOBER 31". I thought that their form letter was nice. Here's what I wrote back. Sent it to pretty much everyone I could email in the Honors Program, from the director on down to the office assistants. My letter follows: Dear Patty, Roberta, and Marlene, Thanks so much for your email. I appreciate your taking the time to write to me. Actually, if you check your records carefully, I took a graduate level class last semester, EPSY 302, which adressed the socal and emotional needs of gifted students in education. Also, I filled out the paperwork to withdraw from the program over a year ago, but apparently that never took effect. But that's neither here nor there. I haven't really ever been involved with the honors program, though I did benefit from a few honors and graduate-level classes, including one English 250 my freshman year taught by a Professor Philips. As an aside, I thoroughly enjoyed the class. Intriguingly, however, it actually did fit the mold that the Daily Campus portrayed for the Honors Program, which is to say that I received an A- for showing up to class, reading occasionally, and tossing in bits of dialogue when I saw fit. Also, the 'required' freshman reading that year, "Amistad", was never included in the class, though it was an excellent read. I found the program extremely inaccessible to me as a freshman music major. The advisor you assigned me, Professor Glenn Stanley, was nice enough, but was not very well-informed about advising or the honors program. Being from out-of-state, and a wide-eyed 'newbie' to college, I desperately needed some guidance. The honors program gave me none. As a result, I became disenchanted with the program in general and sought elsewhere for my guidance and inspiration. Perhaps this is a flaw in the advising system in general, and not your fault. At any rate, I feel you should know about the schism between the music department and the honors program. I've never voiced this until now, so I take partial responsibility for that not changing. I can't place blame elsewhere if I haven't tried to fix it. I'm now at the point where I'm trying to see beyond myself, thinking that maybe I can change things for future classes... for the better. That's why I'm writing you this letter. In closing, I offer my hope that the honors program will reach out to all majors, and bring in minds from the School of Fine Arts as much as, say, the School of Engineering. I feel that there's a void in research among musicians, and I know that we've got some wonderful minds here. Please give them a haven in which they can learn, grow, and question the very precepts they've come to accept. You never know, we might just have the next Nobel Prize winner here under our noses. As for me, I'm doing fine. I've simply found my enrichment elsewhere out of necessity. I wish you all the best for the possibilities of the future. Thanks. Ehren Brown Music Education UConn Class of 2003 PS: Roberta or Patty, if I didn't make this clear, go ahead and take me out of the Honors Program. This just in - over the CMEA wire. Some serious food for thought, I think... ---------------------------- Legislation won't make children learn By David Finley Dec. 10, 2002 Educators know the truth but are afraid to say it: All children cannot learn. I am an educator, and in my profession it is a mortal sin to say that all children cannot learn. Now that I have said it publicly, I will probably lose my job and be excommunicated from my profession. At the very least I am certain it will give Arizona's state superintendent of public instruction a bad case of heartburn. Perhaps I can redeem myself by rephrasing the statement: All children can learn but all children cannot learn as much as all other children. And all children cannot learn to some preset state or federal standard, as is currently mandated by the No Child Left Behind Act and Arizona Learns legislation. I am principal of a school the state has labeled "underperforming." Does this embarrass me? Not in the least. The label is a misnomer. Schools are simply brick and mortar. They do not perform, over or under. The label really means that the school's instructional staff is underperforming. Since I know that the teachers at my school are effective, dedicated professionals who are actually "overperforming," I am not the least bit embarrassed by being mislabeled as a result of this ridiculous legislation. Color me defensive if you must, but I believe labeling schools is nothing more than name-calling, something most of us learned not to do in kindergarten. Labeling schools will not improve them and actually runs counter to the intended purpose. The goal of the law is admirable and sounds great to voters. Schools will be held accountable to ensure that all children learn and succeed; the achievement gap between poor and rich kids will magically disappear; and no child will be left behind. The only phrase missing is that everyone will live happily ever after. Like the emperor in the classic fairy tale, the No Child Left Behind Act has no clothes, but no one is saying so. The punitive nature of the legislation is forcing teachers to teach to a test instead of teaching children; consequently, there may be a superficial rise in test scores. However, for solving the problem of low achievement by at-risk children, it is tantamount to putting a Band-Aid on a headache. Saying that "all" children must achieve to a predetermined standard on a test is like saying that all children in physical education classes must run a six-minute mile on a physical fitness exam. And saying that all children must show one year's academic growth for one year in school is like saying that all children in the school lunch program must gain 10 pounds and grow 2 inches in one year. Children are not created equal in athletic ability or physical characteristics. Neither are they created equal in their ability to learn. Any first-year teacher knows this; apparently politicians do not. They have created a law that is focused on fixing the schools and just possibly the schools aren't broken. I am not saying the schools are perfect or that we cannot improve. And I firmly believe that the education profession must be held accountable for what it does. But this is true of every profession, including law and medicine. The professional educator, however, seems to be at the bottom of the food chain. Unlike any other profession, we are constantly asked to do more with less. And politicians, who say things that are politically expedient but not educationally realistic, relentlessly criticize us. Doctors and lawyers are never subject to such political philandering and shortsighted legislation. Doctors are not required by law to cure all their patients. It is acknowledged that there are circumstances with each patient that are unique. Some patients will not follow their doctor's instructions; some simply have illnesses that cannot be cured. Lawyers are not required by law to win all their cases. It is recognized that every client has a unique set of circumstances that will directly affect their attorney's ability to bring them success in court. Teachers, on the other hand, do not fare so well with lawmakers. The law ignores the fact that schools in the low-income areas serving predominantly at-risk children have much higher percentages of children with special "medical problems and legal circumstances." Under the threat of a "failing label" teachers must cure every child irrespective of his or her illness; win every case in the courthouse of the classroom no matter the legal circumstance of the child. In the Emperor's New Clothes, it takes a small child to tell the truth and bring the adults to their senses. Maybe our legislators need to come into the "underperforming" schools. They might learn some things they did not know before. Perhaps this would bring about some responsible legislation aimed at solving some of our problems instead of creating new ones, such as an exodus of quality teachers from the at-risk schools, where they are needed most. Fairy tales usually have a happy ending, but I fear not with this one. --------------------------- What do you think? Send thoughts to urlLink ehrenbrown@letterboxes.org

I think that this article is absolutely on the mark - so much so that most people will vehemently deny its validity because of the chance that all the ideas they hold true might collapse in one burst of enlightenment. Read it and decide for yourself. U.S. continues war against common sense By Joshua Levinson - Daily Campus, University of Connecticut "This is Stacey. This is the dime bag that Stacey bought. This is the dealer who sold the dime bag that Stacey bought. This is the supplier that smuggled the pot to the dealer who sold the dime bag that Stacey bought. And this is Carla, who was hit by a stray bullet from Stacey's supplier and paralyzed for life. Drug money supports terrible things. If you buy drugs, you might too." This is just one example of a new wave of drug commercials by the Office of Drug Control Policy (ODCP) that prey on the fear of terrorism. Aside from being misleading and dishonest, some of the commercials are so lacking in any sort of common sense or factual information that one can only wonder why they were created at all. In another commercial, we see two men sitting at a table, discussing how drug money supports terrorism. One of them, clearly the sensible one (you can tell he's smart because he's wearing glasses), says that drug money supports terror: it's a fact. The other one, clearly lacking in moral fiber, says, "Let's say I buy some dope. Now how much of my money actually makes it into the bad guy's hands? A couple of bucks. Peanuts." The first man (remember, he knows what he's talking about) replies, "So what you're saying is that it's okay to support terrorism... a little." Now, let's say for a minute that we forget that even the ODCP itself admits that marijuana comes primarily from Mexico and, in some lesser extent, Canada and the United States itself (we are assuming that by drugs, they mean marijuana, since it's the only drug they seem to have commercials about anymore). You want some real facts on funding terrorism? In 1982, Iraq had just been removed from the list of states supporting terrorism, despite evidence that this wasn't true. The Reagan administration then proceeded to give Iraq billions of dollars and military intelligence so that they could win the war with Iran. "CIA Director Casey personally spearheaded the effort to ensure that Iraq had sufficient military weapons, ammunition and vehicles to avoid losing the Iran-Iraq war." Am I making this up? Unfortunately, no. This information is all from a sworn affidavit of Howard Teicher, a member of Reagan's National Security Council at the time. In other words, the United States provided the weaponry and intelligence that Iraq used to win the war with Iran, subsequently, to invade Kuwait, which lead to fighting and the killing of American soldiers. So, who supports terrorism? Our government. I've got a new idea for a commercial: "This is Josh. Josh pays his taxes. This is the IRS, where a percentage of funds are taken from Josh's taxes and given to the government. This is the government, who gave Iraq billions of dollars in aid and military intelligence in order to win the Iran-Iraq war. This is Saddam Hussein, who used the aid in order to kill American soldiers in the Persian Gulf War. Tax money supports terrible things. If you pay taxes, you might too." Does this sound outlandish? It shouldn't, because, sadly, it contains far more truth then the commercials branding people who smoke marijuana as terrorists. Worse yet, another wave of commercials depicts "potheads" in different scenarios, each playing out a different tragedy. In one, a car full of people smoking marijuana at a drive-thru, order food they can't afford. (And just who, exactly, is stupid enough to do this in broad daylight?) They realize they don't have any money and freak out, subsequently peeling out and driving over an innocent little girl. In another commercial, two kids are smoking marijuana in one of their parents' rooms. One of the kids pulls out a gun, but says it isn't loaded. Whoops! Looks like somebody got shot in the face. Yet another death avoidable if only they hadn't gotten high, right? Finally, we have a couple of teenage kids sitting on a sofa. The girl hands the boy a joint and seemingly passes out. Then, he decides to lean over and sexually assault her (grab her breast, in this case). In each of these cases, the camera fades out to the word "Harmless?" Now, as much as we all know that "potheads" are a bunch of date-raping, child-murdering, friend-shooting, terrorist-funding communists who spend their spare time overthrowing the government, I'm beginning to wonder where, exactly, these ideas came from. If the U.S. government must insist on pouring billions of dollars into a "war" that will never be won, no matter how much they sit around and make things up about marijuana, then at least have the decency to use a little thing we call "facts." Nobody ever said marijuana was harmless. But you don't see any commercials with drunk drivers running over little girls, do you? Of course not. Yet this is an infinitely more likely scenario. So what happens when people begin to realize that none of these scenarios are based on anything even remotely resembling a fact? What happens when kids begin to realize that they know people who smoke marijuana and it doesn't make them bad people? When they realize people who smoke pot don't fund terrorism, or rape girls, or shoot their friends in the face? We should no longer tolerate this flood misinformation and dishonesty from our government. They give Iraq and Afghanistan billions of dollars in aid and then act like it's a bunch of hippies' fault? C'mon, give us a little more credit than that. The next time the ODCP tells you that everytime someone buys a dime bag, they are supporting terrorism, who are you going to believe?

"Teaching is a moral and sacred act. I think the characteristics of a good teacher begin with genuine respect for the student's mind. That respect conveys to students that they can take themselves seriously. Next to that, I think, is a real love for the young and joy in seeing them grow and develop. Next to that is a passion for the discipline, but if you lack respect for the young mind and the love of young people, you won't be able to communicate it very well. We can teach people to be good teachers up to a relatively high degree, but I think teaching is also a talent. The really great teachers have this kind of X-ray vision that allows them to look at a young person and see right into that important intersection of emotion and intellect and see how to harness that emotional energy and intellectual effort and bring it to fruition. And that is a kind of X-ray vision that can't be taught. You either have it or you don't." -Jil Ker Conway (author/historian), "In Praise of Our Teachers"

Another from the archives - this is a letter I stole that was posted on a bulletin board at SYMS music camp at the University of New Hampshire in the summer of 1997. It resonated with me then, and it continues to do so now. Turns out this guy was a piano professor at Eastman at the time. ---------------------------------------- Forwarded message Wed. 30 April 1997 Hello all, Ive been thinking a lot about fear, love, and things of that nature. Or put another way, is there any way to be off the path? It seems to me that there are the things that really touch our hearts and stir our souls, and there are things that dont. Somehow, we have been taught that what touched us most deeply isnt the way our lives should go.. Isnt that the thing we should follow Isnt that what we should build our lives onIsnt When we sit at many of our performances, when we play at many of our juries, when we sit through many of our classes, we feel the emptiness in our souls. We are bored. We are tired. This doesnt make me feel good. This doesnt make me feel. At the same time we feel a kind of safety in that. We feel our desire to be purified by our discipline. This must be good for me to feel this bad. And on and on. So what Ive been thinking is that the problem is not in the person/student, the problem is on the interpretation of the person/students growth patterns. The problem isnt in feeling bad, or confused, or lost, but rather in interpreting that confusion as dysfunction or pathology. The fact is growth hurts does it not? Doesnt the bone grow back stronger after the break? Do you put your hand on a hot burner more than once? How can anyone seriously expect to study music, in all its unfathomable mystery, without confusion and pain? Its obviously soul work and can only be related to on that level. Or, we can speak on the other side of the same con. How can anyone look into their own heart without confusion and pain? Of course great beauty and joy go along with all this but Im assuming that everyone realizes this. Anyways, heres the rub, theres no choice. Your soul knows what song its supposed to sing, and either sing it with joy and love and suffer those consequences, or be burdened by the weight of turning from your own heart. It seems that the only thing more frightening than pain is joy. In the Hindu tradition of chakras and the movement of spiritual energy there is the beautiful concept of finally arriving at level 6 out of the 7 chakras. At this point you behold God and it is the most beautiful sight ever imaginable but check it out, theres another level. To achieve it you must let go or abandon the most beautiful thing you have ever seen, Gods image, so that you may merge with it and have no consciousness of it but rather are it. Which actually brings you back to level one, the most basic level. Musically speaking, I think we all realize that Jazz is dead, or at least whats passed off as it nowadays. Or you could say its as alive as the Minuet if you call that living. The question is can you let go of your image of Jazz that everybody shoves down your throat and find the energy behind it, continually being renewed in every generation. Physics tells us that energy just transfers, connect with that and see where it takes you. That may be a book, a TV show, a porn mag, Beavis, a friend, and if youre lucky, MUSIC. And, if youre very lucky, then your own soul. Follow what touches you deeply no matter what. Believe in its own rightness no matter how seemingly crazy Crazy is an external interpretation put on creativity by those living in fear and pain. Your natural design should be your key and guide. Learn from everything around you but always place your inner voice at the highest. Can I get a witness? Hhmm. A little preachy. A few other quick thoughts. Im beginning to think that maybe you guys are the early generation of another 60s type shift in consciousness. Ive seen wisdom and depth in you folks (students) that seem to be more than just smarter. I sometimes think its a quantum type of shift akin to the conservatism of the 50s and early 60s against the love culture of the late 60s and early 70s. For you guys there seems to be a coming together of a lot of things in one mind with a spiritual dimension that seems beyond the clich dogma of our religious institutions. If you are our future, Ill take it. One of my many lessons at McCurdys is that there is no such thing as crazy. I just get paid for my insanity where they get locked up. To feel fear and not show it, to feel anger and not show it, to feel love and be too afraid to say it, to feel sad and be unable to share it, There is no way to be off the path, you dont need to feel frustration or worry, or pain at learning music. Thats crazy. Make music and allow yourself to be swept up in its stream and it can take you to a place beyond fear. And for the love of all thats holy, do not take on anyone elses pain about music. If they are bitter, let them practice making music without joy. Play what feels right, always. You dont have to play any better, because there is no better. Joy is not better than joy. OK, have to run. More shenanigans (sp?) to come. Earnest Borgnine, is anyone with me on this? Michael Cain

Lauren was reading emails from last summer a moment ago... everyone's thoughts after the big Vermont trip, how we felt, how it changed us and the like. It got me thinking. Today was my first day at Lebanon with all the teachers, as a colleague. It was great. I was excited. I am excited. And yet I worry. I worry that I'm forsaking dreams for practicality, and that scares me. I worry that I'm going to become just another person in the system. I feel like I'm already becoming it, even as I fight tooth and nail with my soul. Lauren's somehow managed to avoid this, or at least it seems on the surface. She stays true to who she is, regardless of what happens. It's one of the reasons I'm madly in love with her. And things fall out for her somehow. They always do. And they always have for me, too... as long as I trust myself and hold fast to that which is RIGHT. Am I following my own well-trodden example now? I don't know. Is this... culturation ... happening to everyone, everywhere? Perhaps. But it scares the piss out of me. The idea of becoming a downtrodden drone is more than I can bear. And it scares me enough to do something rash. Heroes can be a funny thing, you know. The man I thought was mine - Jack London - turned out to be not such a good role model after all. Well, maybe he still is a hero, albeit one I now take with a grain of salt. You see, Jack lived hard. And he also died hard, and died far too young. The man took needless risks, put needless substances into his body, and in general asked for what he got. And yet his 'credo' (that hasn't even been proven to have been his words, after all the stock I've put into it!) still rings true for me: I would rather be ashes than dust! I would rather that my spark should burn out &nbsp&nbsp&nbsp&nbsp&nbspin a brilliant blaze than it should be stifled by dry-rot. I would rather be a superb meteor, every atom &nbsp&nbsp&nbsp&nbsp&nbspof me in magnificent glow, than a sleepy and &nbsp&nbsp&nbsp&nbsp&nbsppermanent planet. The function of man is to live, not to exist. I shall not waste my days trying to prolong them. I shall use my time. I'm still so young. And I can see LIFE itself coming at me with all of its excitement. And I feel like I'm turning from the path of LIFE to the path of safety. I hope I'm wrong. At any rate, I'm only tied down for a year. A lot can happen in that time. In a year, my lease and contract will be up for renewal. And you never know what might happen then. I don't have to sign. Then again, maybe I'll still want to. Maybe right now, this is LIFE. Time will tell.

The wisdom of the alders I wrote this in Vermont on Friday afternoon. It's my first poetry in years. Hope you enjoy it. The sanctity of the woods surrounds me. Their solitude supports me. Their stillness speaks to me. They are saying Relax. Be not afraid. We have not come to scare you. We are not here to build you up. We are. Unabashed in our stoicism, We simply exist. And we will Share our secrets with you. If you would only stop to listen! For as long as you come here bearing the scepter of your world, you can never understand. Foolish human! When will you see That your world, as you know it, is Misguided and deluded? That your values are misplaced? That your anthrocentric views are wrong? How can we make you understand That our stoicism you hold so dear, That draws you to us, Is a faade? You see what you expect to see. If you would open your eyes to yourself, You would soon realize that We are always changing. Is this so difficult to grasp? Nothing is ever the same -- and you cannot change that fact. So it is with us. And so it is with you as well. You think you can control your world, bend it to your whim -- you are wrong. You think people are static things -- you are wrong. You think you know what will happen tomorrow -- you are wrong. Only in this one thing may you trust -- that you do not understand the world. It's OK. We don't either. The difference is that we enjoy it that way. We may not know what will happen tomorrow, But we can choose how to face it. All you need do, every dawn, Is convince yourself that today , you will succeed. And it will be so. For when you are faced with adventure or adversity, (Which are really two sides of the same coin) Simply remove all options of failure And make whatever you are given work. ....... What, human? You crave more? There is no more. You now possess the extent of our secrets. What you do now is up to you. Let's see if you are up to the task.

Sometimes I think that I, myself, am the meaning of my life -- that I must find motivation within. Other times I search for it in spirituality or "God" or the church. I think that my problem is that I ask too many questions to be at ease with much. An inquisitive nature is wonderful for finding stuff out, but it runs counteractive to the Zen-like state I crave right now. Richard Shindell is an amazing musician. His cd "Courier" is playing right now in the background, which I cannot recommend heartily enough. I look around my new apartment and I think "Damn, I have it made." I've got all sorts of stuff -- more than I know what to do with, and certainly more than I have places for. But stuff doesn't really mean much in the end. I have a beautiful, wonderful, compassionate, understanding, loving, and caring girlfriend in Lauren. I have a great job that I'm fairly sure I can enjoy and do well in, but that I know is not where I can stay for a long time. None of these things really seems to sink in at times like this. It's like I've got up this shell that blocks out everything -- good stuff, bad, indifferent. It doesn't matter. It's all crap. But it's not crap. And I know that too. I think I'm scared on a lot of fronts. I don't feel like I know myself, not substantially anyway. Do any of us really know ourselves? Or each other, for that matter? Can we? Is it even possible? I am inclined to say YES to all of those questions. I know that people do know themselves, and that people can know other people. I wonder how those people do it. I wonder what I'm missing sometimes... why I can't do it, I mean. Seems like self-knowledge shouldn't be that difficult a thing to do. Lauren walks downstairs and hangs from the beam that crosses the bottom of the stairs. I am struck by how amazingly nonchalantly breathtaking she is. She spins across the room with hands in the air, dancing to music nobody else hears. She pauses at the fish tank to kiss it and commune for a moment, then decides that I might need some company and plunks herself down next to me, where she lies down and nuzzles up persistently under my elbow. Oh, I'm in love. Sounds like somebody knows who I am -- and what I need -- after all. There's hope for us all. Guess I found my point.

Fun with Myers-Briggs I took an online Myers-Briggs personality test tonight at urlLink http://similarminds.com/ and wasn't terribly surprised by the results. The interesting part was that the description I found of my personality type (ENFP) was very accurate. I pasted it below. Give a quick read and tell me what you think. The Inspirer As an ENFP, your primary mode of living is focused externally, where you take things in primarily via your intuition. Your secondary mode is internal, where you deal with things according to how you feel about them, or how they fit in with your personal value system. ENFPs are warm, enthusiastic people, typically very bright and full of potential. They live in the world of possibilities, and can become very passionate and excited about things. Their enthusiasm lends them the ability to inspire and motivate others, more so than we see in other types. They can talk their way in or out of anything. They love life, seeing it as a special gift, and strive to make the most out of it. ENFPs have an unusually broad range of skills and talents. They are good at most things which interest them. Project-oriented, they may go through several different careers during their lifetime. To onlookers, the ENFP may seem directionless and without purpose, but ENFPs are actually quite consistent, in that they have a strong sense of values which they live with throughout their lives. Everything that they do must be in line with their values. An ENFP needs to feel that they are living their lives as their true Self, walking in step with what they believe is right. They see meaning in everything, and are on a continuous quest to adapt their lives and values to achieve inner peace. They're constantly aware and somewhat fearful of losing touch with themselves. Since emotional excitement is usually an important part of the ENFP's life, and because they are focused on keeping "centered", the ENFP is usually an intense individual, with highly evolved values. An ENFP needs to focus on following through with their projects. This can be a problem area for some of these individuals. Unlike other Extraverted types, ENFPs need time alone to center themselves, and make sure they are moving in a direction which is in sync with their values. ENFPs who remain centered will usually be quite successful at their endeavors. Others may fall into the habit of dropping a project when they become excited about a new possibility, and thus they never achieve the great accomplishments which they are capable of achieving. Most ENFPs have great people skills. They are genuinely warm and interested in people, and place great importance on their inter-personal relationships. ENFPs almost always have a strong need to be liked. Sometimes, especially at a younger age, an ENFP will tend to be "gushy" and insincere, and generally "overdo" in an effort to win acceptance. However, once an ENFP has learned to balance their need to be true to themselves with their need for acceptance, they excel at bringing out the best in others, and are typically well-liked. They have an exceptional ability to intuitively understand a person after a very short period of time, and use their intuition and flexibility to relate to others on their own level. Because ENFPs live in the world of exciting possibilities, the details of everyday life are seen as trivial drudgery. They place no importance on detailed, maintenance-type tasks, and will frequently remain oblivous to these types of concerns. When they do have to perform these tasks, they do not enjoy themselves. This is a challenging area of life for most ENFPs, and can be frustrating for ENFP's family members. An ENFP who has "gone wrong" may be quite manipulative - and very good it. The gift of gab which they are blessed with makes it naturally easy for them to get what they want. Most ENFPs will not abuse their abilities, because that would not jive with their value systems. ENFPs sometimes make serious errors in judgment. They have an amazing ability to intuitively perceive the truth about a person or situation, but when they apply judgment to their perception, they may jump to the wrong conclusions. ENFPs who have not learned to follow through may have a difficult time remaining happy in marital relationships. Always seeing the possibilities of what could be, they may become bored with what actually is. The strong sense of values will keep many ENFPs dedicated to their relationships. However, ENFPs like a little excitement in their lives, and are best matched with individuals who are comfortable with change and new experiences. Having an ENFP parent can be a fun-filled experience, but may be stressful at times for children with strong Sensing or Judging tendancies. Such children may see the ENFP parent as inconsistent and difficult to understand, as the children are pulled along in the whirlwind life of the ENFP. Sometimes the ENFP will want to be their child's best friend, and at other times they will play the parental authoritarian. But ENFPs are always consistent in their value systems, which they will impress on their children above all else, along with a basic joy of living. ENFPs are basically happy people. They may become unhappy when they are confined to strict schedules or mundane tasks. Consequently, ENFPs work best in situations where they have a lot of flexibility, and where they can work with people and ideas. Many go into business for themselves. They have the ability to be quite productive with little supervision, as long as they are excited about what they're doing. Because they are so alert and sensitive, constantly scanning their environments, ENFPs often suffer from muscle tension. They have a strong need to be independent, and resist being controlled or labelled. They need to maintain control over themselves, but they do not believe in controlling others. Their dislike of dependence and suppression extends to others as well as to themselves. ENFPs are charming, ingenuous, risk-taking, sensitive, people-oriented individuals with capabilities ranging across a broad spectrum. They have many gifts which they will use to fulfill themselves and those near them, if they are able to remain centered and master the ability of following through.

Words from other people's mouths My first thought to share is the one that's been with me the longest. I came across this about three years ago in Oakland, CA on a plaque enshrined to Jack London. He called it his "Credo": I would rather be ashes than dust! I would rather that my spark should burn out in a brilliant blaze than it should be stifled by dry-rot. I would rather be a superb meteor, every atom of me in magnificent glow, than a sleepy and permanent planet. The function of man is to live, not to exist. I shall not waste my days trying to prolong them. I shall use my time. Next is from T.S. Eliot's poem Four Quartets . These passages are from the fourth quartet, "Little Gidding": What we call the beginning is often the end And to make and end is to make a beginning. The end is where we start from. [...] We shall not cease from exploration And the end of all our exploring Will be to arrive where we started And know the place for the first time. Come to think of it, this next quote has been in my presence even longer than Jack London's credo. It's scrawled in my quote book from February of my junior year at UConn. This thought from Mark Twain - or, more accurately, Samuel Clemens - is most appropriate as I struggle with what to do with the rest of my life, in all aspects: Twenty years from now you will be more disappointed by the things that you didn't do than by the ones you did do. So throw off the bowlines. Sail away from the safe harbor. Catch the trade winds in your sails. Explore. Dream. Discover. I'll write more in a bit. For now, this is enough.

Friends are key I had a party last night. A bunch of my friends showed up and we had a blast. My parties have changed, though. Maybe that's normal. They used to be humongous drunken raves in my apartment in Hilltop. Now, it's different. People have to make an effort to get out here. So it's not just the "let's do this tonight" thing that it used to be. And I think I like it that way. Things haven't really toned down all that much, but anyone who's here is one of my really good friends. That's a difference. Blogs are a weird thing. I have a love/hate relationship with mine lately. I have all these thoughts and feelings that I want to write down, but then I think: do I really want the entire Internet to be able to read all this stuff? Do I want everyone to know what I'm really thinking? Because I've been burned. I've let it happen to me far too many times. And it's left me in a situation where I'm not sure which way is right. Part of me wants to just shut off, becoming untrusting, cloaked, secretive. And I know that will never work. I refuse to become bitter, I refuse to shut down, and I refuse to let my past cloud my potential for happiness. That's exactly what I'd be doing if I did that. Bullshit. But how much sharing is too much? When does a blog turn into an advertisement of weakness? Do I really want everyone knowing when things are shitty? Then there's the other side: if I write what I actually think, it could hurt people. I don't pretend to always have the nicest thoughts. I know that we all have nasties sometimes, those dark little thoughts that we sweep under the rug. I'm not convinced my blog is the place for slandering other people. So that's why my blog hasn't been updated recently as frequently as I (and some of you) would like. I just don't want all my thoughts published out there in cyberspace. I can stay open. I just can't trust blindly. Trust in God, but lock your car. Let art win.
