Never and other forgotten promises For every apparent blessing contains the seeds of danger - every area of trouble gives out a ray of hope - and the one unchangeable certainty is that nothing is certain or unchangeable. John Fitzgerald Kennedy urlLink State of the Union address, 1962 Nothing ever turns out the way we think it will. We live our lives and make our plans for the future, all the while deceiving ourselves that we do not have utter control over our slippery destinies. Relationships -- of all kinds -- originate in the oddest of places. People we once thought we would never talk to again, didn't want to see again, and didn't even want to think about again just fall back into our lives, forcing us to redefine our relationship from what was, but shaped by what we now are. And then there's that word that the English language distilled from many distinct emotions into one ambiguous saccharine package: love. But let's save that part for later. This has happened to me very recently. I never thought I would talk to Lauren again. Well, most of me did, anyway. Hoped for it, wished for it, tried my best to ignore that anything had happened and just cut myself off. I think part of me needed that, and I did an okay job for a while. Things were going well. Then -- surprise -- after several chance encounters where I was able to deal quickly and leave, I found myself in a quandary. I got a call from Lauren saying that Rubyfruit wants to learn the song Northern Cross and she didn't know all the parts and would I please come teach it to them? What a battle. She couldn't have known -- could she? -- that this would put me in a problem with no satisfactory solution. I'd been avoiding her. She must have known. The answer might have been simple: no, thanks. But she asked this at a time when I was craving music on a higher level, when I needed to be around and make music with people who just get it. Add to that the fact that I am friends with several people in the group, and that I hadn't seen them in a while, and the decision became harder. In the end, I ended up deciding that she'd been really nice about it, that I really wanted to make music, that I love the song, and that I should just get the fuck over it and go. I didn't expect to leave feeling any different towards her, but I figured I could make it out all right -- that I'd been scratched up before, and that any negative possibilities were just dwarfed by the positives. So I said sure, why not. Seeing her wasn't the roller coaster I'd worried it would be, though it wasn't without its twists. I wasn't able to eat dinner that night, wondering what would happen, despite Tony and Anagha's best efforts to chill me the fuck out. So I went off to the music building hungry, on edge, and curious. Eventually, Lauren showed up after I'd been talking with a couple Fruits for a bit. People say that whatever doesn't kill us makes us stronger, and I think I'd like to add that it makes us wiser, too. She walked in and at first we barely acknowledged each other, said hi, kept talking, the usual charade as of late. But eventually we locked eyes, and there she was. The eyes don't lie. They're the barometer of the soul. And I'd like to think that what we both saw there was someone who'd been hurt badly and was cautious to try it again, but also someone who wanted to very much. Let me pause for a moment to bitch at the English language for its oversimplification of the word "love". The Chinese have 11 different words that mean love, such as the love between friends, the love between family, or the love of a possession. Most other languages have several variants, but at least more than one all-purpose Wal*Mart of a word our language offers like LOVE. So when I use the word here, my meaning is different than Hallmark and Cupid and all that other commercial crap. What I saw there was love. Sometimes I think that love is like matter -- it can't be created or destroyed, but it can change states or phases to something different. What I saw in her eyes said more than words could. They spoke of past romance, good times and bad, and how that was past now. But I also saw how it had changed, never really died, into something else. We understand each other, Lauren and I. We can annoy the hell out of each other and can probably never have the same kind of relationship we did before because of all we've been through. But with all that time spent comes a bond, an exchange of a bit of self. I feel it with everyone I've ever been close with, even people I haven't talked with in years. Those are the people I remember, the stuff of memories. And they're impossible to erase, even if you try real hard. Part of them is part of you, and somewhere in the middle you change each other. That can't be undone. So we're just kind of looking at each other, and although all of this happens in a second or two, it's unmistakable. We're stuck. Because we've been to hell and back and lived to talk about it. For better or for worse, we're in this for the long haul. In whatever form the universe has chosen to bestow, what I see there is love. I mean something to her. And her to me. And we'll never be what we were. And that's okay. One of the things that drew me to her, way back, was how we clicked better -- musically -- than I ever had with anyone. That hadn't changed on Sunday, as I found out. We split the group into two, and taught the parts we knew best. Then we combined, and I did what I do best (better than her, I suppose?) -- teach vocal music to an a cappella group. And it was everything I needed. I had a great evening. We made plans to meet the next evening in the music building and play guitar and sing. I drove in on Monday around 4:45 and after we ran around for a bit, we went downstairs and played and sang. Still cautious, I had brought printouts of several songs I like that I knew she liked, too, as a peace offering of sorts. The walls were still up a little but the connection had been made the night before. So we sang, for an hour or so. Shaky at first, opening up a bit here, untrusting there, feeling out the other person, but at the end of the hour letting loose with real true music. And it was perfect. I'm still on my guard a little with Lauren. I probably will be for a while. There is a lot of hurt on both sides to get over. But the eyes don't lie. And there is music still unsung.

music -- my addiction I am wasting my life. Or at least it seems that way. Teaching young children is a noble calling and can be great fun -- but it is absolutely not what I want or need to do with my life. I need to make music. And I'm not doing that right now. I need to be creative, to be around people who will sing and play instruments and create something beautiful. I want to dedicate my life to pursuing art and music and beauty. I don't know what kind of music I want to create -- it could be anything that I think I can do well. Choirs and guitar and singing come to mind. Anything, or all three, would be good, I think. I feel like my creativity is stagnating and I'm being suffocated under a pile of irrelevant bullshit -- that is, my life. I sound depressed. I guess I am I do know there is an out. I don't think my life is a dead end. I just think that I'm headed in that direction, if I don't change anything for the better. So I guess I need to do that. But how? Does this mean artistic supplements to my teaching? Does it mean throwing teaching out the window and becoming a professional musician, working shit jobs to pay the rent? Im not really sure what bearing this has on anything, but I just feel like talking. I am alone in the commercial sense of the word. I am not buying Valentines Day jewelry or Valentines Day roses or Valentines Day lingerie (not that I ever did!) or anything else that we are supposed to hold so dear on this one day. My wallet is considerably fuller than it has ever been on this day in the past. And I still feel fulfilled. I think that for the first time in my life, Im enjoying creating my own personality. I have a natural tendency to please. Add that to a long string of relationships, one right after the other, and you get one confused and lost Ehren. Somewhere in the middle of it all, I lost my way. In some ways, for all my bravado, I never had to think for myself. (I wonder how much of this is crap. Have I really just been a puppet for years? Somehow I doubt it. But regardless this is interesting. Lets see where it goes.) Being in a relationship make certain things easy. Who will I hang out with? Right, I have a girlfriend. Problem solved. Who should I ask to go on vacation with? Whoops, forgot girlfriend! Who should I try to have sex with tonight? Well, Im a horrible player, and anyway, I have a girlfriend. So many decisions become easy as a result of having a girlfriend that its been easy to lose sense of ME in the midst of all the US that occurs. The development of the US becomes so important which, in all honesty, it must, to actually create a loving relationship that the ME either ceases development and goes into stasis, or just takes a permanent vacation. Its the second part that I am now famous for, and am now spending energy to examine. Im great at US things: talking, understanding, giving, receiving, just doing nothing together but its the continued development of the ME that I historically have ignored. Sometimes I think I need remedial classes in myself. This is, of course, hogwash. Im the best expert on ME there could possibly be. Nobody else has lived with ME for quite so long as I have, so I know the idiosyncrasies of ME impeccably well. I even hear my voice or to be more correct, voices trying to tell ME what is really going on in my head and what I should do about it. Voices, you say? In my head? Hes nuts! People dont have voices in their heads telling them what to do. Not normal, everyday, good people like us. Yes, you do. We all do. Each facet of our self our personality our ME has a voice. And it talks to us. Not about things like aliens invading our mattress or conspiracy theories involving our pet rat (well, not usually), but about the decisions we face everyday. They talk to us and tell us what they would do and what we should do and pretty much try to run our lives. As long as you realize that theyre merely parts of ME and not individual entities, theyre perfectly healthy. Its called self-awareness. Its called listening to your heart. Its called following your dreams. Theyre all our concept of the voices. So we all have voices in our heads. And they talk to us. But I dont always hear them. And that is the problem so many of us face. We ignore the voices. Whether we pretend they dont exist, or get so good at ignoring them that we manage to shut them out altogether, the outcome is the same. We deny the voices the right to speak. And in doing so, we cut ourselves off from the one thing that can show us how to bring fulfillment into our lives the ME. Your ME knows what you need. It gets it, understands it all. By ignoring it, youre ignoring your own true feelings, needs and wants. Why would you do that? Maybe youre scared of what might actually happen if you follow your dreams. Dream-chasing can be a dangerous business. What if you fail, and your dreams go up in dust? Can you handle that? Better to just keep your head down and not try. But you know, deep down, that you cant do that. Because youve been doing it, and look where you are. Youre unhappy because youre ignoring your voices and they dont lie. But they can be misunderstood. You see, they dont always speak plainly. Sometimes they talk to you in riddles, sometimes in Greek. And sometimes they dont talk at all, but simply exude intent that youre just supposed to get. Hell, its hard to understand. But theyre part of you. If you dont figure out how to hear them, who will? And what will become of you if you dont figure out how to listen to yourself? Im somewhere in the middle of this journey right now. Im realizing that I have ignored my voices for a long time, and am trying to get back in tune with my ME. But I dont really understand yet what its trying to say. Its speaking in languages I dont yet understand, but will someday. I know that something is not right, but cant see far enough yet to figure out what IS right. Its a nebulous place Im in. I could fight it, just go do something, anything , but what good would that do me? I really need to just be still and listen. Give myself time to filter out the static. And the understanding will come. I cant bear the thought of wasting my life on useless endeavours. I wonder if thats possible. But for now I need to stay in gentle motion, while quieting my heart. Once I can do that, then I will begin to understand what the voices are telling me. And this thing called life will start to make sense. Im not angry at Valentines Day. Im not sure I ever was. But I almost feel sorry for myself, for the way I used to feel it was all so necessary to be complete. Because loves not about one day. Thats called lust. I know that now. Love is something far different. It requires the continued development of the ME while pursuing the US. Its a balancing act between the two that takes time, patience, and commitment. And I will find it again. Maybe this time, Ill be ready for it.

Ruminating Back to bed didn't so much happen. I made it INTO bed, only to have my mind start philosophizing... so blogging it is. There are times in our lives when everything slows down... when we can toss off our cares and routines to just breathe a little slower and think a little more clearly. Today seems to be one of those days for me. I can hear people tromphing around in the apartments next to me. Considering it's 6:23am, I can only assume that they're getting their souls ready for work or school or whatever it is that they do each day. And I am here in bed, listening to it all. The noise they make isn't much... in fact, sometimes it dies down completely. But I know that in my little space I call home, there are at least two people who are not thinking the same way I am right now. How can they? How can someone follow their morning routine, coaxing their body into one more day, while stepping back from the whole thing to just think? They'd be late to work. Or they wouldn't go at all. It's an interesting concept. Why do we go to work at all? The easiest answer is "to make money". But I'm not sure of that. Seems like, if I really wanted to, I could save enough money so that I wouldn't have to work all the time. We spend so many hours a week putting up with crap -- for what? So that we can have a more expensive car? A bigger house? "We clutter the earth with our inventions, never dreaming that possibly they are unnecessary -- or disadvantageous. We devise astounding means of communication, but do we communicate with one another? We move our bodies to and fro and incredible speeds, but do we really leave the spot we started from? Mentally, morally, spiritually, we are fettered. What have we achieved in mowing down mountain ranges, harnessing the energy of mighty rivers, or moving whole populations about like chess pieces, if we ourselves remain the same restless, miserable, frustrated creatures we were before? To call such activity progress is utter delusion. We may succeed in altering the face of the earth until it is unrecognizable even to the Creator, but if we are unaffected wherein lies the meaning?" &nbsp&nbsp&nbsp&nbsp&nbsp-Henry Miller Am I making my point? Why do we hold things so dear that mean nothing at all when you change from a zoom to a panoramic lens? The big picture is everything. Or at least it should be. I just can't help but feel that we've lost our way. And I don't think I'm the only one. Is anyone with me on this?

Sitting For a brief while, I sit. The world whooshes by. Things are not always what they seem. I don't need to be everything to everyone. I only need to be myself to me. My sense of self has developed a case of wanderlust lately, leaving to wander as it sees fit. Occasionally it graces me with its presence. For a brief while, I sit. Understanding fills the void. I understand that dreams are crucial to survival. I know now that not even lemmings follow each other blindly where they're told (a common misconception started by Disney), and human beings certainly should be no different. Sadly, this is not the case. People are lemmings more than lemmings are lemmings. For a brief while, I sit. Jazz wafts to my ears. Many things are important. Not every desire can be fulfilled. But I need to be me. And I'm finally beginning to understand the implications of what that means. For a brief while, I sit. Everything begins to focus.

From March 6th This story was written by Leila and I on March 6th at Fitch High School in Groton, CT. I got this idea from Meaghan and Erik and modified it -- on the ACDA trip to San Antonio, we rotated writing sentences; here, each of us took turns writing paragraphs. If you know us, it's pretty easy to figure out who wrote what. I don't think it'll be submitted for publication anytime soon, but it's worth a read. Have fun -- we did :). Once upon a time, a cat sat on my head. It kept me awake all night. And I yelled at it. But not too loud. By the way, the cats name was Keegan OMalley. As you would expect, he was from Greece. His owner used to call him her little Greek olive. He didnt like the nickname (as it made him look like a sissy), so he hopped the first boat to the old country. Thats Poland to you. So Keegan, being a trilingual refugee, decided to eat pork for dinner. While in Poland, Keegan discovered the wide world of Catholicism. The polack kind. And at Christmas, little girls would wear wreaths on their heads, with candles in them. Keegan had adopted a little girl to be his person, and he was shocked and dismayed when she fell asleep in her candle crown. Keegan barely made it out in time. The girl was not so lucky. But staring at the beauty of the flames, Keegan realized that his true calling was as an arsonist. He met his first obstacle when he tried to strike a match. Drat humans and their opposable thumbs! He tried cigarette lighters and flint and steel, all to no avail. He was about to give up the arson idea completely when he finally came up with a way to ignite his glorious blazes. On a pondering-type walk through a park one twilit evening, Keegan fell asleep and dreamed. In the dream, he saw a shape smokifying around in the shadows. He meowed out, and who should appear but the cloven-footed darling of the underworld? With a very hazy middle, Keegan remembered vaguely wishing he could start fires, a brief mention about something to do with souls, and suddenly, with a start, he awoke! The wet grass tickled his nose, and with a sneeze, the nearest tree ignited. Toxic boogers are cool. The fire jumped from the first tree to another, and another, and still again, swiftly turning the dry forest tinder into a raging inferno. Keegan leapt to his hind legs and danced a whirling dervish as he rushed toward town, away from the hellfire he had sneezed into being. Traveling by boat became a problem, but Keegan kept lots of benadryl handy and eventually made it all over the world. Given that the devil had him in thrall, he lived a very long time. He lived, in fact, until the end of the world. And when Jesus came down with his flaming sword..poor Jesus. Keegan had a cold. The end.

Why I don't want to be a teacher I was going to save this tirade for another time, but it needs out. So here goes. Our educational "system". It's this noble thing, education. Priming the young minds of today so they can become the leaders of tomorrow. Work hard, be a good person, and life will hand you bliss on a silver platter. It just ain't so. To get to the core of the problem, we need to go back to why public schools -- or compulsory education, for that matter -- began in the first place. It all goes back to child labor laws. Until 1938, children could pretty much work any job they wanted, for as many hours as they wanted. And they did. Large families were in vogue. More children meant more laborers, which equaled more money for the family and -- usually -- more food on the table. Nobody gave this a second thought. School was something for the rich upper class, and everyone else when they could fit it in between work. Enter the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) of 1938. Suddenly, there was a societal push to "protect" our children. And yes, this was a new concept. Until then, the concept of childhood as we know it simply did not exist. Children were not coddled or protected, they were introduced into the world quite early and expected to adapt. Life was hard. Someone, somewhere decided this simply could not do, and that our youth needed to not be exposed to these (admittedly) severely harsh conditions of factory work and the like, as well as working the long weeks that had been common. Children everywhere were probably grateful. Working conditions were pretty bad, and to get out of them must have seemed like a great idea. This raised, however, the pressing question of what to do with all these recently liberated youth -- who were now roaming the streets and getting into all sorts of mischief, as idle children are wont to do. Somebody came up with the idea of creating schools, great centers of learning, where the children would be taught. "Yes, that's it!" they must have said. The idea was embraced. Unfortunately, most humans suffer from a lack of vision and truly original thought. This being the Industrial Revolution, the schools were modeled after the only system most people knew: the factory. And thus schools were damned before they even started. What do we teach our students? Some say languages and sciences, others would say arts and philosophy. The sad truth is that these disciplines -- and I use that word purposefully, disciplines -- are little more than vehicles to teach our children the one true task: to conform. Oh, we make it look good. Most of us even manage to believe otherwise. "Oh, my schools weren't like that ," you say. "We were encouraged to think freely and be our own person." Really? Remember elementary school? Those early formative years? What happened to you when you got out of line because you wanted to? What happened when you just had to share the latest gossip during a math lesson? Or consider this: when did you plan your own day at school? Did you ever get to decide what you would do? I mean, really decide, not just decide given a certain set of choices. The choiceless choice is the teacher's best weapon against student unrest. "Look," they say. "You can choose what you're going to do." Bullshit. They've already decided for you. They created the choices, and whatever you pick will still fit into their agenda. It's all about control. Perhaps you've heard it under a different name: citizenship. To be a good citizen... now that's certainly something I remember learning about in school. Remember the Pledge of Allegiance? Do you remember reciting it every day in school with everyone else in eerie unison without questioning why? Did you ever have a Jehovah's Witness in your classroom who remained sitting during the Pledge? Did you think he/she was different because they didn't conform? Why are you not saying the Pledge? How could you NOT pledge allegiance to the flag or the President or Allah or whoever? Children are taught to follow directions and not speak out of turn. Creative divergent thinkers, or disruptive students as teachers call them, are squashed as quickly as possible. These are ideal traits for factory workers, who perform mundane tasks every day without question or thought. They are not ideal for today's world. Can you imagine a world with leaders who are truly divergent thinkers? People who weren't afraid to try something radically different? People who could see the bigger picture? Maybe someone who could actually see that war begets more war and nothing else. But I am forgetting that our children are created by the system. A system with centuries of history that is bent on perpetuating itself. Creating original, divergent thinkers would be counterproductive to the goal. And so we are stuck in a cyclical paradox, unable to extricate ourselves from the loop. I don't know how much longer I can rail against this bullshit. Being part of this system makes me sick. It's like the Borg. The best I can figure is that I will either give in and become assimilated or become an El-Aurian of sorts who resists successfully but who is forever outside the world that most people know. Open your eyes, people. I don't care if you think it's bad or good. But I don't think you can shoot a hole in my logic about the reality I'm describing. If you can, please do -- I could use a better outlook.

I am completely zenned out. Today has been amazing -- and it's only noon! We sang "The Creation" in church today. It's a rock cantata from 1970 based on the text from Genesis. The performance today was complete with piano, bass and drums and was just amazing. It's 1970's gospel rock at its finest. The interesting part is that, from a technical perspective, it wasn't perfect. Not by a long shot. There were holes, voices sticking out, stuff like that. But we all came together for a whole that was more than the sum of its parts. Twice, I almost lost it because I got chills and everything was just washing over me. This music isn't classical. Not by a long shot. Several of my purist friends would shun it (and already have -- though without ever hearing it...) based on this fact alone. I can understand their viewpoint. There's a lot of music in this genre that is crap. It's too bad that people oversimplify things and say "I don't like ________". We miss out on so many gems that get overlooked because of the cheesy "Yay God" Christian pop music that people associate with the genre. Music is music. Beauty is just that. And it can be found in the unlikeliest of places. Places where all else is dark or ugly. Or maybe we just perceive it so. And the beauty is there, perhaps on the surface for all to see, maybe buried under layers of dust, maybe tucked in behind some things we don't like all that much. This is as much a tirade to myself as it is to everyone else, I guess. I wish I could just move above all the petty bullshit that drives the world and really, really see the beauty and good in all things. Sometimes I get it right. But as far as I'm concerned, sometimes isn't often enough. Perfection is worth striving for, in this case as well as others. I've got to believe in people. If not, I might just lose faith in everything. And that's a world I don't want to be a part of.

And still it rains. Water falls on water. For forty days, No sun, no moon. It seems like it's been raining for weeks. Until today, the rains have dampened my spirit as surely as my skin. But today I found a window back to a place I used to visit... a place where rain can be relaxing and even comforting. Maybe it's summer approaching, with the relaxation and freedom it brings. Maybe it's the warmer rains that come with the change in the seasons. Whatever the reason, the rain tonight was relaxing. I walked out of church at into a dark drizzle when it had been sunny and clear a few hours earlier. My immediate reaction was "Come on now, I'm so sick of the rain!" But as I dampened on the walk to my car, I found myself relaxing... accepting... almost enjoying the wetness as it hit my skin. There's something equalizing about getting wet by the rain, as though it brings a sense of solidarity to all who are touched by it. Nobody can escape it or buy their way dry. If you are out, you get wet. Period. Being able to hole up somewhere during a big storm is very cozy, just as wandering in a downpour is freeing to the soul. I would do well to remember that side of rain, instead of considering only how the rains mean that there is no sun. The sun will be back. In the meantime, I still have much to learn from the water.

"Often I feel I go to some distant region of the world to be reminded of who I really am. There is no mystery about why this should be so. Stripped of your ordinary surroundings, your friends, your daily routines, your refrigerator full of your food, your closet full of your clothes -- with all this taken away, you are forced into direct experience. Such direct experience inevitably makes you aware of who it is that is having the experience. That's not always comfortable, but it is always invigorating. "I eventually realized that direct experience is the most valuable experience I can have. Western man is so surrounded by ideas, so bombarded with opinions, concepts, and information structures of all sorts, that is becomes difficult to experience anything without the intervening filter of these structures. And the natural world -- our traditional source of direct insights -- is rapidly disappearing. Modern city-dwellers cannot even see the stars at night. This humbling reminder of man's place in the greater scheme of things, which human beings formerly saw once every twenty-four hours, is denied to them. It's no wonder that people lose their bearings, that they lose track of who they really are, and what their lives are really about." --Michael Crichton, Travels (1988)
